titleStmt.title:
Indigent Hospital Patients Admitted for Treatment
in Duval County during Year Ending June 30th, 1915.
titleStmt.author: Name of author of document goes here

publicationStmt.p: This document forms part of the project "Editing the Eartha M.M. White Archive" at the University of North Florida.

msIdentifier.repository: University of North Florida, Thomas G. Carpenter Library Special Collections and Archives

objectDesc.p: A description of the object, including its material (type of paper, etc.), dimensions, number of pages, print or handwritten, etc., and some mention of its condition, if relevant.

editorialDecl.p: This file was transcribed and encoded according to the editorial criteria of the project "Editing the Eartha M.M. White Archive." Using the various options encoded within <choice> elements, this file enables the viewing of a diplomatic transcription and a regularized reading text.

row.cell: Percentage of County Realty Taxes Derived from City Realty
Percentage of County Realty Taxes Derived from Country Realty
Percentage of Number Admitted for Treatment at expense of City
Percentage of Number Admitted for Treatment at expense of County

body.p:
During the year ending June 30th, 1915, Duval County, and City
of Jacksonville, spent $46,393.58 for the care of indigent hospital
patients. If all these cases could have been cared for at the County
hospital, the total expense would have been not over $33,000.00, estima
ting upon the basis of the expense incurred by the county for care of
cases handled at the county hospital. In other words, if the county
hospital facilities had been adequate to handle all the indigent hospit
al cases that devolved upon the public during that period, a saving of
at least $13,000.00 of the tax payers' money would have been effected.

Not only was this extra expenditure necessitated by lack of
adequate facilities but the county authorities were prevented from ef
fecting many economies that might have been possible with a better
equipment, and from furnishing the public the emergency hospital service
that is so urgently needed. In short, the enforced neglect of many de
serving cases in this county that has resulted in probably preventable
deaths because of the lack of adequate public hospital facilities, is
so disgraceful a matter as to be no longer tolerated by a civilized
community.

To carry a bond issue of $120,000.00 - the amount needed for
the erection and equipment of an up-to-date hospital building of approx
imately two hundred bed capacity - would necessitate the assessment of
$10,000.00 annually or one-quarter mill on a dollar valuation, for in
terest and sinking fund, an amount $3,000.00 less than the possible sav
ing in the indigent hospital expenses incurred within the county last
year. This possible saving would be augmented by the returns from in
terest on the sinking fund accumulations and by the increased economies
that could be effected if indigent cases, and pay cases at cost, could
be handled in one properly designed and adequately equipped institution.
The expense for caring for indigent patients at St. Luke's hospital last
year was approximately, $2.00 per day's treatment; at the county hospit
al, approximately, 80 cents per day's treatment.

City Commissioners:
T. I. Imeson, Chairman,
Ernest Anders,
Dr. M. B. Herlong,
Fred Valz,
St. Elmo W. Acosta.
